41FBF7EBD1C84CF1A181D03011137357.description: recognize the purpose of environmental laws

CC09F466AD994AA0985B5D0786C2761E.description:
examine the relationship between land-use practices and altering ecosystems (e.g., swamp
drainage, slash-and-burn forestry, agriculture)

074D6F8D341C4DA6A571D202AF9D1414.description:
examine how interactions among organisms limit populations (e.g., predation, parasitism,
competition)

409268693C784EA19A564C54A73D1072.description:
explain how various factors influence the size of populations (e.g., immigration, emigration,
birth rate and death rate, food supply, predation, disease, number of offspring produced, climate
change)

605EE0D4BB0F40B7A88C78A85420FA23.description:
examine how various abiotic factors influence biodiversity in an ecosystem (e.g., climate,
substrate, temperature, elevation)

682BBEB630354C97BA247FBB3C4E9C0D.description:
define ecosystems in terms of biotic and abiotic factors (e.g., common plants and animals,
latitude, altitude, topography)

280FD7E5ADE54789A5C2228908EDCE77.description:
describe in general terms, the characteristics of two Alberta biomes (e.g., parkland, boreal forest,
mountain, grassland)

1E822D3C23BC41358D6CB21500A0DF28.description:
examine a local ecosystem in terms of its biotic and abiotic components and describe the factors that
maintain its equilibrium

3453D788C4834F0D800DC3F038870F84.description:
identify the needs and interests of society that have led to technologies with unforeseen
environmental consequences (e.g., fishing technologies that result in harvesting rates that are
higher than reproduction rates, use of pesticides such as DDT, impact of automobile emissions
on atmospheric composition)

EA5ADBEE001743C381548B0A8C3D9A43.description:
examine the impact of modern agricultural technology on the cycling of matter through natural
pathways

E224DE69C96F4FA6BA1107A660C487EE.description: compare the recycling of matter by society with the natural cycling of matter through ecosystems

27E76C52716641DCB06B5E57206D61E2.description:
examine how biodegradable materials reduce the impact of human-made products on the
environment

DD526ABA775A43C2A4392E33B7EEA5E2.description:
examine the costs and benefits of technological developments that result in materials the
ecosystem cannot recycle (e.g., disposable plastics, heavy metals)

FB5C9551203C4067A01EB5B9AD6F2FDF.description:
investigate how human societies, including traditional Aboriginal societies, influence the cycling
of matter in the biosphere

D0D965237B104011B40F63AD5A6B5B9D.description: examine natural food chains, food webs and energy pyramids

21C3F76667D8418D86DCCED48849A336.description:
examine how the flow of matter in the biosphere is cyclical along characteristic pathways and can be
disrupted by human activity

9245A5A5A1E04E19B29E95E1A3E5C0E0.description: Investigating Matter and Energy in Environmental Systems

0E5196D3EA254577917F36144FE52D0D.description: identify the role of modern technology in monitoring critical life functions in humans (e.g., ultrasound, heart monitor, blood pressure cuff, blood glucose monitoring devices)

5118840987874CD69B2031157B240563.description:
examine how cell structure is adapted for specific life functions (e.g., stomata on the leaves for
water balance; skin cells are flat to cover a large surface area; plant cell walls provide
structural support; nerve cells are long for transmission of impulses; storage of chemical energy
in roots such as sugar beets, stems such as sugar cane and fruits such as apples)

52C0F78AE8B941BA94193EFC0CC7760B.description:
identify the major human organ systems that perform critical life functions (e.g., energy
conversion, response to the environment, growth, reproduction, conservation or dissipation of
thermal energy)

3A6C1AC6BEF146BFB8D6DCBF4B3852F4.description: identify the organs and systems in plants and animals that perform life functions

3C4D5A7489B84D5CB7661C14558B3A78.description:
examine life functions common to living systems (e.g., energy conversion, response to the
environment, growth, reproduction, conservation or dissipation of thermal energy, torpor,
dormancy, hibernation, estivation, vascular skin, sweat gland behaviour)

62B5DEF1BB3F44A2B3B8825163FE5FFA.description:
examine the relationship between photosynthesis and cellular respiration in terms of biological
energy storage (e.g., capture of energy from the sun in glucose during photosynthesis and the
release of energy from glucose during cellular respiration)

D0840E52CEDC4AE98D9980B3B51D4CDA.description:
identify and compare, in general terms, the life functions common to living systems, from cells to
organ systems

DC1C65A3511A4163998F1035A40F718E.description:
examine the structure of the major parts of plant and animal cells, including the cell membrane,
nucleus, vacuole, mitochondrion, chloroplast and cell wall

B4717C08B4764FE1A79409B99D8B29EE.description: describe, in general terms, the structure and function of plant and animal cell parts

7201651544DB47CF8034F4616B50C031.description:
examine the effect of social factors on human digestive and circulatory well-being and disorders
(e.g., ulcers, anorexia, bulimia, high blood pressure, heart and arterial diseases, as they relate to
fitness level and diets)

96B28E8372A9441D87F8152B33A756BF.description:
examine a technology that is used to diagnose imbalances (e.g., endoscope, stethoscope) or to
intervene and preserve balance (homeostasis) (e.g., kidney dialysis machine, pacemaker)

3F7D76DA1958400C922DD0AFA37E48BC.description:
explain that illness and possibly death may result when the body cannot accommodate major
disturbances (e.g., appendicitis, kidney failure, heart attacks) within the digestive, excretory and
circulatory systems

E399C42D83134DEA810864214EC7C803.description:
describe, in general terms, how the digestive and circulatory systems interact to assist in the
maintenance of balance (homeostasis) in the human organism

D3C4E0AA80C64CE3A6E17CA9E3C420A3.description:
examine disorders of the digestive and circulatory systems induced by genetic, lifestyle and
environmental factors

239450E387E344AE96C94CEFFA85D262.description:
describe, in general terms, the role of the heart and lungs in the circulatory system and in the
exchange and distribution of matter processed by the digestive system

6D8D338C189648EDB5FFDFD6E9CE66B7.description:
examine the intake and processing of matter by the digestive system (e.g., foods are broken down
into molecules that are absorbed into the blood stream from the intestine, food intake leads to
increased blood sugar and mineral levels)

C3AA3D846B42408DAE903EA7A146D635.description:
recognize how diet/eating habits, other than traditional foods, have impacted Aboriginal and
other cultures

509260EDB44E48A8B00D8A777ED83900.description: examine and discuss the role of mixed and vegetarian diets in meeting human nutritional needs

B0BD2073EBAB4E47BF3EFCA09B83D7B7.description:
explain, in general terms, how diets that include excessive amounts of certain foods may
influence body function (e.g., foods high in cholesterol, salt, fats)

F36731E08506460BA94B044A3354D143.description:
assess the nutrient components of prepared foods by reading labels and evaluate a variety of
popular diets in terms of nutrient composition

10626292F2054FAA8A6A68F1922E73F6.description:
investigate human nutritional needs using Canada’s Food Guide to Healthy Eating and other
resources

77DDB678280E4E4DA074516745645D6C.description:
examine, in general terms, the exchange of matter by the digestive and circulatory systems, the
functional relationship between the two systems and the need for a healthy diet and lifestyle

D9A0272229724E499E4511E72851868E.description: Investigating Matter and Energy in Living Systems

46821E12AFCC4A6FB54A6BA85FA6E67D.description:
examine common household machines in terms of force multipliers and ways in which work is
made easier (e.g., can openers, crowbars, automobile jacks, scissors and hedge clippers).

8520707DD4094FC1B6ABE53E09255FD7.description: describe simple machines as either force multipliers or distance multipliers

1408BCEB4FA9454B9C4D05D9DFDE92DA.description:
describe simple machines as devices that transfer energy (e.g., screws, ramps, hammers, hockey
sticks, tennis rackets)

F8B498390DC040DD953A3C5428BC0E2F.description:
describe and compare simple machines as devices that transfer energy and multiply forces or
distances

52A52EF273E94EB6BA84B7269E72A6B6.description:
examine variations in absorption or loss of heat in a substance being heated or cooled by
manipulating variables, including the amount and type of material (e.g., motor oil, cooking oil,
water)

EB15D299C8164D308E0A142CC65262F6.description:
examine devices and methods that protect against potentially dangerous thermal energy transfer
(e.g., household appliances, protective clothing worn by firefighters, internal combustion engine)

04D7FE80036F49D98F6E8ECDA229A5F5.description:
investigate technologies that reduce thermal energy transfer (e.g., clothing construction
strategies, insulation, cavity walls)

5DA63FCB44C64439916126E4A0D5B406.description: investigate common methods and devices designed to control the transfer of thermal energy

5823460D7B0A4CCC852616832BB34DDF.description:
describe how large bodies of water, such as oceans and lakes, have a moderating influence on
climate (e.g., compare the climates of Vancouver and Calgary)

1F65547012074FDA8A60C97730384811.description:
examine the roles of convection and conduction in distributing heat in natural and technological
systems (e.g., sea and land breezes, cast-iron pots and pans)

2A325C974178401195BE1DC0BA5ADCFA.description:
describe the particle model of matter, in which every object consists of particles in motion, and
describe the effect of temperature on this motion (e.g., observe Brownian motion)

39A2C60A4E274D2EB61CE18A3A7C6FCF.description:
compare and evaluate the efficiency of contemporary structures to traditional Aboriginal
structures in terms of heat retention

AB5D823FC2B24D2199B1A9124E4CD3F5.description:
describe the three ways (e.g.., radiation, convection and conduction) thermal energy transfers
from warmer to cooler objects

F792C9E6EA1F46B59A78234D6627D458.description:
observe cooling systems as applications that are based on the principle that heat transfers from
warmer to cooler objects (e.g., air conditioners, automobile radiators)

2B4D4B2FE2004D6589767BD8117913C4.description:
examine how natural and technological cooling and heating systems are based on the transfer of
thermal energy (heat) from hot to cold objects

5B35A4884CA3440C9C229F714DBF5C95.description:
identify and write word equations for common elements and simple compounds (e.g., hydrogen
and oxygen produce water, iron and oxygen produce rust, carbon and oxygen produce carbon
dioxide, sodium and chlorine produce salt)

EF6884EABFF943C282416A4912F9726B.description: use the periodic table to locate the names and properties of elements

0E1745165AFC494B80AEF22EF0E754B4.description:
describe the difference between metals, nonmetals and metalloids on the basis of their properties
(e.g., luster, conductivity, malleability, brittleness, state of matter)

C69AEF903A1841329B25CAEB9E610CBC.description:
identify that elements can combine to form compounds and that compounds break down into
their constituent elements

211BD799F2AA4A16B17CF43353187D07.description:
describe the properties of elements and compounds and have a basic understanding of the periodic
table

C58D4E67C3924701886B9AF1245185F1.description:
identify the potential dangers of mixing common household and industrial chemicals (e.g., not
mixing ammonia cleaners with bleach, not adding water when diluting acid)

F47EB33988CE4919B71D5600A1F71F60.description:
investigate the corrosive effects of environmental factors such as acids, bases, salts, humidity and
temperature (e.g., corrosion of iron by acid rain and spray from ocean water)

A47423D2B2EA46F1B9A0726A36A53E20.description:
describe, in general terms, the pH scale as an indicator of acidity or basicity (e.g.., a pH of less
than 7 indicates an acid, a pH of greater than 7 indicates a base)

FC9ABC735C3B41B987744CAC921C3851.description:
compare the volume of packaging waste resulting from the use of concentrated and diluted forms
of products (e.g., orange juice, fabric softener) and relate this to the need for recycling and
environmental preservation

1D7584987FBB4903AAE8FF323656E1B4.description:
describe examples of the effect of temperature change on solubility and explain this effect on the
basis of the particle model of matter (e.g., concentration of brines for pickling and syrups for
canning)

4CD167603EFD45908C24D3349BFA612F.description: provide examples of mixtures that do not form homogeneous solutions (e.g., oil and water

559D930DD9D341C3B588003FAED89D34.description: provide examples of mixtures that form homogeneous solutions (e.g., vinegar and water

61924556922D4521AE31627C5FC355D4.description: define solute, solvent, solution and solubility

4A435E01780E444FBA0620F05DC7EEE4.description:
describe solutions and solubility, solutes and solvents and describe how these concepts are applied to
the production of prepared foods and useful materials

C7900B54363646669EF15C77CBE4F4AC.description: apply the particle model of matter to explain the physical properties of the phases of matter

AD132F4473CF45C392AED9652D83F175.description: differentiate between the physical and chemical properties of matter

BDB93125E1034A1285B4F98CC8F6BCBB.description:
relate the properties of pure substances and mixtures to practical applications (e.g., salting icy
roads, adding antifreeze to automobile radiators)

A2FCF1CECA944EAAAF585B690AD9DD8D.description:
compare and contrast the properties of pure substances and mixtures (e.g., zinc and brass, iron
and stainless steel, acetic acid and vinegar, pure water and salt water)

A4BBAF600F664DBCBE0ED8B51CA82975.description:
communicate and demonstrate safe handling, storage and disposal of household and workplace
substances using the Workplace Hazardous Materials Information System (WHMIS) and
Household Hazardous Products Symbols (HHPS)

7ACD4AD3817E4A63BF77B55D0783635A.description:
classify various forms of matter, including commonly used household substances, on the basis of
their properties and relate theses properties to their safe use, storage and disposal
